#Brewers return home a very symmetrical ballclub. They are 26-18 at home and on the road.
Brett Anderson, Jake Cousins, Brad Boxberger and Hunter Strickland combined for three-hit shutout in nightcap vs. Mets.

#Brewers bounce back after blowing two late leads in opener to blank Mets 5-0 in nightcap of doubleheader. It avoids three-game sweep in New York and prevents four-game losing streak before returning home for big series vs. Cincy.

Luis Urias, whose day began with a home run off Jacob deGrom, ends his day (we hope) with a long two-run homer against Miguel Castro and #Brewers lead 5-0. That's 12 dingers for Urias, whose starting to show the power of a third baseman.
They showed Josh Hader stretching in #Brewers pen. Perhaps he pitches twice today?

That might have been most remarkable inning by #Brewers reliever this year. Brad Boxberger walks the bases loaded, then strikes out next three hitters and all good ones -- Lindor, Smith and Alonso. What a turnaround. He threw 36 pitches, faced six hitters, and no balls in play.
After walking bases loaded, Boxberger gives himself a chance to escape sixth by striking out Lindor and Smith. But Mets' best power hitter, Alonso, is up next.
I should be there Friday.

After Boxberger walks first two hitters and goes to 3-0 on the next hitter, #Brewers finally get someone up in bullpen. And Boxberger walks Villar on four straight pitches. Three straight walks in a 3-0 game and he's still pitching.
Brad Boxberger enters game with 3-0 lead in the sixth and walks the first two hitters he faces, Nimmo and McNeil, both pinch-hitters. Asking for big trouble here.
Brad Boxberger comes on for #Brewers in sixth.
On Base Jace Peterson gets on for third time on walk in sixth but that's all for #Brewers, who lead 3-0 on the Adames homer.
Willy Adames, who was 0 for 6 with five Ks in the doubleheader, leads off #Brewers sixth with no-doubt HR off Smith and the lead is 3-0.
Jake Cousins pitches a 1-2-3 fifth inning. What a find he has been for #Brewers bullpen. Six hitless outings (opponents are 0 for 21) with 12 Ks in 7 1/3 innings.
#Brewers go down in order in the fifth. Yelich lined out to deep left for third out. With 2-0 lead, Jake Cousins on to pitch.
Brett Anderson is done after four strong innings. First game off IL so I guess they are being careful but he pitched very well. Three hits, no runs.
Brett Anderson works around leadoff hit by Lindor in the fourth, getting Alonso to ground into DP. #Brewers lead 2-0 and Cy Stock is done for the night. Drew Smith on for the Mets.
"On Base" Jace Peterson leads off #Brewers fourth with single but Pina grounds into DP and Bradley strikes out. The lead remains 2-0 against Robert Stock and the Mets.
Brett Anderson pitches a 1-2-3 third inning and #Brewers still lead Mets 2-0 in Game 2.
#Brewers go down in order in the third against Robert Stock. They still lead 2-0.
Brett Anderson has his sinker working early tonight. Two scoreless innings, five groundball outs. #Brewers lead 2-0.
Manny Pina was 1-for-41 and 0-for-18 but he just hit a 3-2 fastball from Robert Stock out to right-center for a two-run homer in the second. That had to feel good.
#Brewers starter Brett Anderson allows two-out hit in first by Dominic Smith but that's it. No score after one.
Jandel Gustave becomes 53rd different player #Brewers have had on roster this year, tying franchise record set by 1969 Seattle Pilots and matched by 2018 #Brewers.

Rowdy Tellez's first hit with the #Brewers is a two-out single in the first inning of Game 2 that sends Christian Yelich (one-out walk) to second. But Tyrone Taylor bounces into a force at second and that's it in the first against Robert Stock.

Robert Stock has pitched once in majors this year, for Cubs. On June 16, he pitched against Mets at Citi Field with this line: 4 IP, 4 H, 5 R, 5 ER, 6 BB, 3 K (11.25 ERA). Six days later, Chicago put him on waivers and of course the Mets claimed him. First MLB start since then.
#Brewers are facing RHP Robert Stock in second game, a pitcher recently claimed off waivers from the Cubs. A real journeyman playing in ninth organization.
Reds won in Kansas City so #Brewers need to win second game of doubleheader vs. Mets to avoid losing 1 1/2 games in the standings. Lead is currently 5 1/2 games.

New first baseman Rowdy Tellez figures he should feel right at home with the 'Milwaukee Blue Jays.' In #Brewers notebook, I address the hugeness of upcoming seven games in a row against the Reds.   https://t.co/4pFIvF82Vw via @journalsentinel
Somebody forgot to tell Ohtani it's hard to hit in the majors this year.
Lefties were batting .208 against him and the Mets had a bunch of lefties due up.
He was up four times in bullpen but sat down when #Brewers stretched lead in ninth. Hey, he gave up a homer. He's human. It happens. But hasn't happened to him all year, so count your blessings.
Coiunsell said he liked the matchups vs. LH hitters for Suter in the 8th and would have gone with Boxberger in 9th if it was still tied. Said inning fell apart when he hit Smith, the first batter.
#Brewers indeed will add RHP Jandel Gustave as the 27th player for Game 2. That means he has to be added to 40-man and there is an opening.

#Brewers had leads in 7th and 8th innings of scheduled seven-inning game and what has been a very good bullpen couldn't protect them. It was set up to beat deGrom but they couldn't finish it off. Very tough loss.
#Brewers lose, 4-3, on two-run single by Jeff McNeil in bottom of 8th. Never recorded an out in the inning.
Both teams having trouble throwing strikes with game on the line in the 8th. McNeil up with bases loaded and no outs.

Suter thought he had McCann struck out on 2-2 changeup but it was a hair low. McCann fouls off 3-2 pitch and draws a walk on the ninth pitch to load the bases with no outs. Suter and #Brewers in big trouble now.
Suter hits Smith with a 2-2 pitch and Mets have two one with no outs in eighth for McCann.
Willy Adames strikes out and #Brewers leave bases loaded but they accept the gift run from Diaz and take a 3-2 lead. Brent Suter coming on to pitch.
Urias draws Diaz's second consecutive walk to load the bases and then Diaz hits Yelich with his first pitch to force in the go-ahead run. Amazing.

With Peterson placed on second base, Rowdy Tellez makes his #Brewers debut leading off the eighth and strikes out against Mets closer Edwin Diaz. Jackie Bradley Jr. grounds out to short, with Peterson moving to third, and PH Tyrone Taylor walks to keep inning alive for Urias.
So, we go to extra innings at Citi Field, or as we used to call it in the majors, the eighth inning.
That was a first-pitch fastball from Hader at 96 mph that Peraza knocked out of the park.
That was the first HR off Hader this year. He was 20 for 20 in save opportunities.
Pinch-hitter Jose Peraza homers with one down in the seventh and #Brewers closer Josh Hader has his first blown save of the year. Mets tie it 2-2.
#Brewers take 2-1 lead to bottom of the seventh. Let's see how Josh Hader does pitching for first time in eight days.

Counsell moved Corbin Burnes to first game for matchup with deGrom and got what he wanted: 5.2 IP, 6 H, 1 R, 1 ER, 0 BB, 8 K. #Brewers have 2-1 lead in 7th and it's set up for Hader now. Amazingly, he hasn't pitched since June 29 vs. Cubs.
Williams nicks Conforto with a pitch and Mets have bases loaded with two outs in sixth for Guillorme.
Josh Hader hasn't pitched since June 29 so he certainly would be well-rested for four-out save but Counsell hasn't used him for more than three outs all season and has stuck to that formula.

Burnes strikes out Lindor and Smith in sixth but Alonso laces a 3-1 cutter to left-center for a double and McNeil dribbles an infield hit to the left side of the mound. Runners on first and third and that's all for Burnes. Devin  Williams coming on in a 2-1 game.
Luis Urias collects his second hit off deGrom with a one-out single in the sixth but Yelich grounds sharply into a 4-6-3 double play. #Brewers still hold a 2-1 lead.
Same as always. Five innings.

The Mets do indeed try to utilize Nimmo's speed on a steal attempt of second but Narvaez throws him out and Adames makes a great tag, coming in front of the bag and then diving to get Nimmo. #Brewers lead 2-1 after five innings.

With runner on first and one down in Mets fifth, Nimmo hits popup into shallow left-center. No #Brewers defender takes charge and it clangs off glove of charging Yelich, who then throws to second for a force. But Mets exchange fast runner for slow one (Nido).
Tomas Nido leads off Mets fifth with chopper that Urias muffs on a short hop for an E-5. deGrom tries to bunt him up but pops it up and Urias charges in to catch it.
That was a 2-2 slider on the inner half from deGrom that Peterson smashed out of the park to right-center. #Brewers have only two hits off deGrom in five innings but they are both big flies.

Avi Garcia is robbed of bloop hit to center by charging, diving catch by Nimmo to open 5th inning. But there is no robbing Jace Peterson, who follows with a home run to center off deGrom. Peterson has been something the last few weeks for #Brewers, who take 2-1 lead.
You failed to mention the back issue that sidelined him for over a month this season.
A 1-2-3 fourth inning by Burnes. The expected pitching duel with deGrom is developing after each allowed a run in the first.
deGrom strikes out the side in the fourth. The second K vs. Adames was 1,500th of deGrom's career, in his 198th game. Only Yu Darvish (197 games) got there sooner.

Two at-bats for Christian Yelich vs. Jacob deGrom, two called third strikes. Entered game with .441 batting average (15 for 34) vs. deGrom, highest avg. vs him of any MLB hitter with at least 20 at-bats.
Burnes and deGrom have settled in since first inning. It remains 1-1 as we go to the fourth.
Nine up and nine down for deGrom after leadoff HR by Urias.
Nido singles with one down in Mets second but deGrom, a .387 hitter, lines out to second and hot-hitting Nimmo strikes out. #Brewers and Mets still tied 1-1 after two innings.
#Brewers go down in order in the second against deGrom as Garcia, Peterson and Hiura all ground out.

After Lindor's bloop RBI single, Burnes strikes out Smith looking. Alonso singles up middle and WP moves runners to second and third but Burnes whiffs McNeil and Conforto grounds out to second. It took Burnes 26 pitches but he battles and holds Mets to one run. So, 1-1 after one.
Mets get the run right back off Burnes as Nimmo leads off with double to left-center and scores when Lindor bloops a single into shallow LF. Run-scoring schtoinker and it's 1-1.
After the Urias home run, deGrom struck out Yelich and Adames, then Narvaez grounded out to third. That was the #Brewers first inning.
Luis Urias was 1-for-19 on this trip to Pittsburgh and NY before hitting that leadoff HR vs. deGrom.
Here's the HR by Urias. 99 mph on outer half and he pulls it out to LF. Goodness.
Pretty amazing HR by Urias off deGrom to start the game. It was on a 99-mph fastball on the outer half yet he pulled it out to LF. Pretty good bat speed there.
We are underway at Citi Field as #Brewers and Mets play Game 1 of their makeup split doubleheader. And it starts with a bang as Luis Urias leads off with a home run off Jacob deGrom. Wow.
This is #Brewers second doubleheader of the season but it is the Mets' ninth! Nine doubleheaders and we're not even to all-star break yet.
Anderson was already on 40-man roster. We're talking 40-man roster.
Lorenzo Cain has been on the injured list with a hamstring injury but is leaving today to join Class AAA Nashville on a rehab assignment. Hopes to rejoin #Brewers later in month.

Rowdy Tellez said he joked to Jackie Bradley Jr. about being on the same #Brewers team after seeing him rob hits with Boston while Tellez was in Toronto: "I said, 'Dude, I'm glad we're finally together. Now I get to watch it and appreciate it.'

I'm going to throw an interesting name out there as possible 27th player for #Brewers in doubleheader today: RHP Jandel Gustave. He's not on the 40-man but there is an opening after trade of Richards and DFA of Robertson.

So, #Brewers have DFA'd Daniel Robertson and replaced him with Rowdy Tellez on the roster. They haven't announced yet Brett Anderson is activated for Game 2 but presumably he'll take traded Trevor Richards spot on roster. That still leaves a 27th player to be added for twin bill.

FINAL: The Angels defeat the Red Sox, 5-4, to win the series and go 5-1 on the home stand.   The team is 44-42, two games above .500 for the first time since they were 9-7.  Walsh hits 2 HRs, Ohtani hit 1, Fletcher extended his streak to 21 and Iglesias got his 18th save.
The Angels moved Rengifo to left after his miscue in right field. Ward is in right field, where he played the first seven innings...
Mike Mayers did a nice job escaping the jam. Allowed an earned run that was more on Rengifo. M8: It's still 5-4, Angels.
A triple and a double for the Red Sox on consecutive pitches. It's 5-4, and there's still no outs.   The triple came on a bad mis-play by Rengifo in right field.
Jared Walsh hits his second home run of the day. Went 406 feet to right field.   He has 22 home runs.
Angels get a huge break on a call at second base. Didn't look like Iglesias touched the base on the 4-6-3 turn. Went to review and they didn't change it. It's 4-3, Angels, M6.
Ohtani and Jared Walsh go back-to-back. This was a line drive to center field.   The Angels lead 4-2 in the 5th.  It went 435 feet, two more than Ohtani's.
The 32 home runs are now the most in a single season for a Japanese-born player in MLB history. Passed Hideki Matsui, who had 31.
He pulled a line drive 433 feet.
Shohei Ohtani hits No. 32. The Angels now lead 3-2. Line drive to right field.  Every day he does something amazing.
The Red Sox tie the game, 2-2, on an Alex Verdugo bloop single. But Heaney gets out of it.   M5: 2-2.

The process is explained a bit here:  https://t.co/TLNJCL2lBu  The commissioner's office only has 2 spots it can give to position players, so the best route for someone like Schoop was to get voted in by players.

The selection process goes...  Fans->Players->MLB  By the time the selection reaches MLB, if you're a team that doesn't have anybody on the roster, there's a good chance your rep is going to be a reliever.   That's why it probably came down to Soto or Cisnero, not Soto or Schoop.

Hoyer on #Cubs next phase as "rebuild" (2/2):  "We are going to have roster turnover. That was inevitable. ... This is certainly not a rebuild by any kind of definition that we'd be using from our past."

Hoyer on whether to call #Cubs' next phase a rebuild (1/2):  "We're in a different situation now than we were in 2012. The decisions we're making, the processes we're going through are completely different. That label is certainly something to be avoided. ...
"I'll be on the phone a lot in the next three weeks." --Jed Hoyer

#Cubs Hoyer on Arrieta:   "Given what he's done for us in his career, given the highlights he's had and the talent he has, you want to exhaust everything...  "I think with a few tweaks he might well get back to being a really good starting pitcher again."

Hoyer says rookie LHP Justin Steele will be stretched out to "well more than a two-inning role; I think we're going to certainly try to put him in a role where he can face the lineup a couple times." #rotation

Hoyer (cont.) 2/2: "...But when you're in this moment and you're playoff odds get into single digits at this time of the year you have to keep one eye on the future and think about what moves you can potentially make that can help build the next great Cubs team."

More from #Cubs' Hoyer:  "There's nothing that says we can't roll off a bunch of wins here. We've done it. We were one of the best teams in baseball for a pretty long stretch. So we've certainly done it. And there's no reason to think we can't do it. ... (1/2)

More from #Cubs' Hoyer:  "We went through a 12-gamer in 2012 on a 101-loss team. And going through a losing streak like that with this much talent was certainly not something we anticipated and obviously disappointed."

#Brewers bounce back after blowing two late leads in opener to blank Mets 5-0 in nightcap of doubleheader. It avoids three-game sweep in New York and prevents four-game losing streak before returning home for big series vs. Cincy.

Luis Urias, whose day began with a home run off Jacob deGrom, ends his day (we hope) with a long two-run homer against Miguel Castro and #Brewers lead 5-0. That's 12 dingers for Urias, whose starting to show the power of a third baseman.

That might have been most remarkable inning by #Brewers reliever this year. Brad Boxberger walks the bases loaded, then strikes out next three hitters and all good ones -- Lindor, Smith and Alonso. What a turnaround. He threw 36 pitches, faced six hitters, and no balls in play.
Willy Adames, who was 0 for 6 with five Ks in the doubleheader, leads off #Brewers sixth with no-doubt HR off Smith and the lead is 3-0.
Jake Cousins pitches a 1-2-3 fifth inning. What a find he has been for #Brewers bullpen. Six hitless outings (opponents are 0 for 21) with 12 Ks in 7 1/3 innings.
Brett Anderson works around leadoff hit by Lindor in the fourth, getting Alonso to ground into DP. #Brewers lead 2-0 and Cy Stock is done for the night. Drew Smith on for the Mets.
Manny Pina was 1-for-41 and 0-for-18 but he just hit a 3-2 fastball from Robert Stock out to right-center for a two-run homer in the second. That had to feel good.
That was the first HR off Hader this year. He was 20 for 20 in save opportunities.

Burnes strikes out Lindor and Smith in sixth but Alonso laces a 3-1 cutter to left-center for a double and McNeil dribbles an infield hit to the left side of the mound. Runners on first and third and that's all for Burnes. Devin  Williams coming on in a 2-1 game.

Michael Pineda's big league career began in 2011, and today marked the first time he's ever allowed 12 hits in a start.  His previous career-high of 11 came all the way back in 2015.  He had not allowed double-digit hits in a start as a Twin before today.

Kenta Maeda, who has yet to allow a run in high socks, said after the game that maybe it's time for him to throw his long pants out of his locker.  Minnesota starters have a 2.29 ERA since Kenta changed up his socks.

#MNTwins 4, Tigers 2.  The record: 37-50  Kenta Maeda threw five fantastic innings and the Twins' offense again surged for a late, game-winning rally. Maybe Kenta's socks are the difference, after all.

Pablo Reyes flies out to LF and Miley has seven shutout innings and 2-0 lead. His defense rescued him in that frame.

Reds' defense is saving Miley in the seventh. Peterson leads off with single but Winker throws him out at 2B tying to stretch it. After bloop double by Hiura, SS Farmer goes deep in hole on bouncer by Pina and throws him out with Votto making scoop.
With Winker on second and two down, the #Brewers intentionally walk Votto. Miguel Sanchez wild pitches the runners to second and third but strikes out Suarez to keep the deficit at 2-0.

Jesse Winker wins 11-pitch battle with Miguel Sanchez to double in a run. Fouled off four consecutive 3-2 pitches, just barely getting piece of changeup on pitch No. 10. Reds know lead #Brewers 2-0 in 7th.
Wade Miley leads off Reds seventh with double to RF off Sanchez and continues to third on throwing error back in by Garcia. #Brewers bring infield in and Sanchez strikes out India.
Eric Lauer is out of game after this pitching line for #Brewers: 6 IP, 4 H, 1 R, 1 ER, 4 BB, 3 K.

Wade Miley continues to mow down the #Brewers. They have one hit through four innings -- a double by Adames in the first. Cincy leads 1-0.

More from Yelich: "It's been two years but it's 400 at-bats. A really shitty 400 at-bats but I think today was positive. Just finding something to build on. I definitely know I'm capable of playing better."

Yelich did assure us that his back's OK, that it's not his health that's holding him back from being the hitter he was two years ago. "I feel fine; I'm good." He did admit, "I don't even look the same up there right now. Literally, we're starting from square one."

On what's holding him back, Yelich said, "It's been a lot of things really, the last two years. It's hard to explain quickly. I'm trying to figure it out. Me and Andy (Haines) have been talking about it. I know what I want to do. It's just a matter of being able to do it."

More from Yelich: "We've got a lot of season left. Just keep grinding. Try to help the boys. We've got a winning team; we've been playing well. We've been playing good; getting contributions from everybody. Somebody different every night coming up with a big hit."
Christian Yelich hasn't lost his sense of humor. We asked him what he was doing with his early on-field session and replied, "Learning how to hit again."

Toboni said Sox realized Mayer would be available to them around when Rangers took Leiter.
Toboni described Mayer as having ‚Äòa passion to be great.‚Äô He thinks he‚Äôll impact the development of other minor leaguers around him.

Toboni was at a workout for Mayer in the fall, spent perhaps 10 minutes with him. Six months later, Toboni went to see him in a game, stood by the batting cage. Mayer took a swing, looked back and asked, ‚ÄòWhat are you doing here, Paul?‚Äô
Toboni identifies Seager and Brandon Crawford as comps. For Crawford, Toboni notes ‚Äòcocky‚Äô pregame fielding routine - fielding balls between legs, making flashy plays that are fluid, effortless.
Toboni says Sox expect Mayer to stay at SS, even as he adds size/strength. ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs got such purity to his game.‚Äô

Area scout JJ Altobelli ‚Äòwouldn‚Äôt stop‚Äô raving about Mayer - leadership, makeup, skills. Toboni says Sox had a ‚Äòrobust process‚Äô led by Altobelli for 14-15 looks with several other Sox scouts covering him.‚Äô
Sox scouted Mayer extensively in 2019 when Eastlake had another first-rounder. ‚ÄòThe conversation would always turn back to this incredible HS SS who was a sophomore at the time.‚Äô
‚ÄòHe does everything at a pace that it looks so, so easy.‚Äô Compares him to a QB who makes the game look easy.

Toboni on Mayer: ‚ÄòBig kid. Probably 6-3. He‚Äôs never lifted a weight before. He moves with such loose, comfortable actions. That excites us as scouts. We see a lot of runway with him moving forward. ‚Ä¶ He has such natural feel and natural instincts for the game.‚Äô
Red Sox amateur scouting director Paul Toboni on whether he thought Mayer would be off the board: ‚ÄòI think that‚Äôs fair to say.‚Äô

From earlier this year: A look at Barnes‚Äô growth in the organization since he was drafted 10 years ago, with thoughts from the scout who signed him, Ray Fagnant  https://t.co/Na46vnS40n via @BostonGlobe
Bloom on willingness to invest in a reliever: ‚ÄòWe have a lot of faith in who he is.‚Äô
‚ÄòThere really wasn‚Äôt a place I wanted to play that wasn‚Äôt Boston‚Ä¶The grass isn‚Äôt always greener on the other side.‚Äô
Barnes: ‚ÄòI just wanted a fair contract for what I was doing‚Ä¶This is just a place I wanted to stay.‚Äô

Chaim Bloom on Barnes deal: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a great day for the Red Sox. ‚Ä¶ Matt has established himself as one of the better relievers in baseball‚Ä¶Beyond that, he‚Äôs exactly the type of person you want representing the organization.‚Äô
Barnes on 10 years with the Sox since 2011 draft: ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know if there are words for how fortunate I am. ‚Ä¶ everything they do from top to bottom is how you expect it and how it should be.‚Äô

Matt Barnes starts by thanking the organization - owners, front office, coaches - and his family. ‚ÄòThis is a first-class organization that treats us like family and provides a winning opportunity every year‚Ä¶this is a dream come true for me.‚Äô
Cora: ‚ÄòPeople don‚Äôt talk about Christian V√°zquez enough. He‚Äôs one of the best catchers in the big leagues.‚Äô

Cora says Barnes walked into his office this spring and said he wanted to be closer. ‚ÄòWhen he walked in this year, I said, ‚ÄúOK, cool. This might be the route we go this year.‚Äù‚Äô Cora had already decided he wanted more bullpen structure and appreciated Barnes offering clarity.
Cora on first half: ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre solid all around. We‚Äôre not great, but we‚Äôre good.‚Äô
‚ÄòThis is the best version of Matt.‚Äô

Cora on first half: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs been great. ‚Ä¶ There are a few things we have to do a lot better and there are a lot of things we‚Äôll be continuing.‚Äô He cites defensive improvement and avoidance of early deficits as first two areas to improve.

Cora on Barnes: ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs been amazing for us not only this year but throughout his career. ‚Ä¶ Very proud of him. The fact that he and the organization were able to get this done in the middle of the season days a lot about where we‚Äôre at and the player.‚Äô

Terms of Barnes deal, which is two years, $18.75M with an option:   2022: $7.25m 2023: $7.5m 2024 Club Option: $8m Buyout: $2.25m Signing bonus: $1.75m Total guarantee: $18.75m  The team option can escalate by $2m based on games finished over the course of the contract.
By the end of his deal, Barnes could rank second all time in appearances by a Red Sox pitcher. He‚Äôs been a source of stability for a long time - and now looks to remain so for more years to come.
The deal runs from 2022-23 and will include an option for another year in 2024.

Final: Indians 14, #Royals 6.   Mike Minor allowed six runs in the fourth inning and Cleveland did not look back from there, scoring at least one run on on every KC reliever. The Royals have now lost four in a row and are on the verge of being swept here tomorrow.
Kyle wins that one, striking out Bradley swinging on a 94-mph fastball. Bradley singled against Kyle in Triple-A earlier this year.
Royals reliever Kyle Zimmer is facing his brother, Bradley Zimmer, for the first time in the Majors right now. They faced each other in the Minors earlier this year.

That's a pretty good catch by Royals specialist Bill Duplissea. Second baseman Cesar Hernandez didn't touch the bag on the force out, and the Royals won the challenge. Dozier is safe at second, Soler at first with no outs.

Cleveland keeps pouring it on. Amed Rosario lines a ball to the top of the left-center wall for an RBI double. It's 9-3, and that'll be it for Ervin Santana. Richard Lovelady on the mound now in the bottom of the sixth.
Great pop time and throw from Sebastian Rivero, but it was just a little bit too late. Call is overturned, Cleveland wins the challenge and Bradley Zimmer gets a stolen base. #Royals

It's 7-3 now on Andrew Benintendi's solo shot in the sixth, his 10th of the season. Connects on a 3-2 fastball and launches it 420 feet to right-center field.
Here's Ervin Santana for the bottom of the fifth. Minor's line in his final start before the All-Star break: 4 IP, 9 H, 6 ER, 1 BB, 2 K. 66 pitches, 47 strikes. #Royals
I'm not sure what Jorge Soler saw or was thinking as he rounded first base there, but it didn't end well.

After the Royals took the lead in the bottom of the fourth, Cleveland not only took it right back but gave itself a four-run lead. Mike Minor allowed six runs, starting with a leadoff walk, then five hits and a three-run homer to cap it off. Ervin Santana is warming in the 'pen.

Cleveland gets one back in the bottom of the fourth, but they don't tie it because Michael A. Taylor, Nicky Lopez and Salvador Perez combine to get Franmil Reyes out at home on Bobby Bradley's double. One out for Minor. #Royals
No. 21 for Salvador Perez. His two-run blast went 418 feet and snapped an 0-for-12 skid for him.  #Royals are up 2-0 in the fourth.

An awkward catch at first base had Carlos Santana in pain in the bottom of the first inning. Looked like Dozier's throw on a bunt down the third base line pulled Santana into the path of the baserunner. But he stayed in the game after getting checked out by trainers.

@MattF811 @dangainor Exactly. Although Mayo was 4th round.

@dangainor I guess in theory. But the ‚Äúlesser players‚Äù are often high schoolers who have major leverage with secure college commitments. You ain‚Äôt getting em for $250K. But for $1.25M you may convince them.

@dangainor So basically if a first-rounder is taken at a $6M slot. And Os pay him $7m. They need to underslot someone (or the rest of the group collectively) by $1M to stay at budget without financial penalty. Same in reverse. Underslot top pick to pay more than slot later.

@dangainor Can do it in a tweet. Since 2012, each spot in top 10 rounds is assigned a money value (slot). Each team also gets an overall value for all those rounds. You go collectively over that number, you pay penalties. So the goal is to stay within that total budget.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if you can necessarily see it on the field, but the guys were tired. We really had to dig deep."  Mets crawled to the finish line of their sprint to the All-Star break ‚Äî 33 games in 31 days ‚Äî with a winning record of 17-16 in that stretch.    https://t.co/MbRmQCys5K
Mets lose, 6-5.  This felt like their worst of the year.  They are 47-40 to enter a much-needed All-Star break.

Wilmer Difo slices the go-ahead run to left and Pittsburgh has a 6-5 lead. Remember, Pirates were down 5-0 before clawing back.  Mets went to sleep at the plate after putting up a five-run spot in the first inning. The Pirates have out-hit the Mets 15-7 so far today.
Edwin Diaz has blown his second save of the year. He was *this* close from locking it down, but John Nogowski prevailed with a game-tying RBI single.   5-5 in the ninth.
Edwin Diaz lets out a roar after striking out the first two batters of his five-out assignment. After walking Rodolfo Castro, Diaz was nails.
The Pirates have the go-ahead run on first base and Edwin Diaz is being asked to lock down the five-out save in a bullpen game with few arms left.
Francisco Lindor has reached base is all four of his plate appearances today. He's 3-for-3 with a home run and a walk.  His last 10 games, including today: .366 BA, 2 HR, 10 RBI

Rodolfo Castro's second home run of the day, this time off Jeurys Familia, brings Pittsburgh to within one run of the Mets in the sixth. That's only the second HR Familia has allowed this season.  Mets still lead, 5-4.
Now Michael Conforto goes yard to straightaway center, just his third home run of the season and first since May 1.   Mets take a 5-0 lead against Chase De Jong and the Pirates in the first.

Francisco Lindor crushes a monster two-run homer to right-center in the first inning. That was his 11th of the season and it traveled 418 feet, nearly landing on Shea Bridge.   Mets have an early 2-0 lead over the Pirates.
Easy enough first inning for opener Aaron Loup. Strikeout, groundout, strikeout. I'm sure the brews await, but maybe he can pick something better than Busch Light?
Jacob deGrom already threw his side session this morning. He will not be one of the arms the Mets use in today's bullpen game.

The commissioner's office should be fining the umpires, not the players, but of course they can't and won't because of the union thing.
Damn. Terrible year for injuries and now one of the best joins the casualty list.
More from Counsell on Libka's call: "It's an umpire getting involved when there wasn't any reason to be involved."

#Brewers manager Craig Counsell on umpire John Libka's call on Yelich on 1B line: "That's a clear case of an umpire kind of making something up or thinking he sees something that has no influence on the game, and then making a call. There's nothing there."
#Brewers manager Craig Counsell on the umpiring in this series: "I feel like it's been a rough series for the umpires. There's a lot of guys upset on both teams."

#Brewers catcher Omar Narvaez on the ball-strikes call by Doug Eddings crew in series: "It's been really unbelievable, what we've been seeing these last 3 days. It's out of our control. We've got to keep pushing and playing hard and try to adjust to what baseball is giving us."
#Brewers pitcher Freddy Peralta on the umpiring by Doug Eddings crew: "They are doing a really bad job. First game, second game and tonight, too. They need to be better on both sides, like I said."

#Brewers Freddy Peralta said the umps in this series "need to be be better on both sides." Said ball-strike calls have been bad in all three games and reiterated "on both sides." Said he thought the 2-2 slider to Castellanos was right on bottom of strike zone.

Reds beat the #Brewers in a dispute-filled game, 4-3, to trim another game off their lead in the NL Central, pulling within five games. They meet again tomorrow, then three times in Cincy after the break.

Eugenio Suarez takes a 2-0 fastball from Josh Hader out to right to open Reds ninth and Cincy takes a 3-2 lead. Hader had allowed no homers all season and now has surrendered two in last three outings.
Josh Hader on to pitch for the #Brewers in the ninth.
As we go to ninth at American Family Field, it's #Brewers 3, Reds 3 and umpires 3 (ejections).

With two on and two down in #Brewers eighth, Jace Peterson strikes out after what he thought was high second strike call by Morales. Slams his bat down at the plate and walks off. It's 3-3 as we go to the ninth.

Willy Adames is angry at umpire for not giving him time as he stepped out on a strike. And now Brach is mad the ump didn't give him strike three call on next pitch. This would be funny if it wasn't so sad. As I said, umps are THE story in series. Ain't supposed to be that way.
Yes, and he just gave the ump the stare about it. One thing you have to say about this. Umps are equal opportunity bad in this series.

Tyrone Taylor, who replaced Christian Yelich when he was ejected in the sixth, blasts a two-run homer off Brad Brach in the eighth to tie it. Brach wasn't happy with ball-strike calls on walk to Urias before the homer but what's new. That's the way this series has rolled.
Yes, the fans came to watch umps eject Craig Counsell, Christian Yelich and Joey Votto. Great promotion for the game on a national TV broadcast.

Onward with the umpire crap show in Milwaukee. Now it's the Reds who get a taste of it as third base umpire Doug Eddings ejects Joey Votto over a check-swing call. These umps have been THE story of the series, not the players. MLB should be so proud.
Amir Garrett strikes out the side in the #Brewers seventh. Reds still lead 3-1.

Vladimir Gutierrez out of game for Cincy. #Brewers won't be sorry to see him go even though he had no strikeouts in six innings. In three starts against them, he has allowed five runs in 19 innings (2.37 ERA).
Check out India's tag of Yelich. Does it look like he thinks Yelich is going to be called out? Methinks not.
#Brewers try to score Narvaez from first base on double into LF corner by Garcia but Reds make perfect relay 7-6-2 to get him at the plate and Cincy keeps 3-1 lead after six.
This umpiring crew has distinguished itself in all of the wrong ways. They have become THE story of the series. They are not supposed to be THE story.

The umpire crap show continues at American Family Field. Christian Yelich safe at first on wild throw on bunt attempt. Makes a slight move but no real attempt to go to second. India tags him and umpire John Libka calls him out. An irate Yelich gets tossed and crowd is going nuts.
Brent Suter comes in and mows down next three hitters but Reds have 3-1 lead boing to bottom of sixth.

What Peralta needed was the "everything is a strike" zone by O'Nora and Eddings in first two games of series. Then, Counsell figured Peralta got squeezed, and that's enough. Morales paying for the sins of his fellow umps in previous two games, and there were many.

This is what likely got Counsell ejected. He had something to say to Morales after the three-run homer, no doubt telling him that pitch No. 5, a slider, should have been called a strike. Then Peralta hung one and it got rocked.

Freddy Peralta hangs a 3-2 slider to Castellanos and he knocks it out for a three-run homer to give Reds a 3-1 lead. He is out of the game and now Counsell has been ejected by home plate umpire Gabe Morales.

Freddy Peralta nicks India with a pitch (he didn't try to avoid it) and then Jesse Winker beats the shift by bouncing a grounder through the left side for the Reds' first hit of the game. Two on, no outs, for the heart of Cincy lineup, beginning with Castellanos.
#Brewers go down in order in the fifth and the pitching duel between Peralta and Gutierrez continues. #Brewers lead 1-0.
Freddy Peralta has allowed no hits through five innings but also has thrown 82 pitches, which is a lot. #Brewers lead 1-0.
Yes, the umpiring has been bad (for both sides), but that's not why Brewers have dropped two in a row to Reds  https://t.co/zkRygPUpKM via @journalsentinel
Scary, scary story.

Scout Ty Blankmeyer said playing hockey as a kid really helped Sal Frelick's hand-eye coordination, which translates to bat-to-ball skills. See, kids, it's OK to play other sports. You don't have to do just one thing. He was also an elite quarterback.
Yes. He is very, very fast Eugene. Prototype CF, leadoff hitter with great contact skills. Guess what? He doesn't strike out much. That should make him stand out!

Brewers select Sal Frelick, a speedy, athletic centerfielder from Boston College, with first pick in MLB draft. Updated with great quotes from area scout Ty Blankmeyer.  https://t.co/j3xIfaBoUJ via @journalsentinel
David Krynzel.

As for #Brewers taking two college CFs in first round in consecutive years, Blankmeyer said, "You've got to go for baseball players with talent and tools and makeup. If you get enough of those guys, over time it's going to compound and you're going to get a lot of big-leaguers."
Blankmeyer said Frelick has 70 speed scouting-wise but plays at 80 speed in the game. Said it plays in every facet of his game. And stood out in a very tough ACC this year.
Blankmeyer said Frelick "might be small but his game is big in many different ways."

#Brewers area scout Ty Blankmeyer says Sal Frelick "has that it factor when he walks on the field." Said he is a "really exciting player, a special athlete." He's 5-9, 175 but Blankmeyer says "he plays bigger than his stature."
@BaseballAmerica has Sal Frelick rated as the No. 9 player available in draft and #Brewers got him at No. 15.
Frelick is great athlete who played football and hockey. Only 5-9, 175 but is a competitive player and sparkplug, aggressive player.

#Brewers select Boston College CF Sal Frelick with No. 15 pick in first round. An elite athlete who can run, play defense and leadoff type hitter. Second year in a row they've taken a college centerfielder.

#Brewers pitching prospect Ethan Small finished the NL's 8-3 victory today in All-Star Futures Game. He had a rough patch with three hits and two runs in two-thirds of inning but struck out the last two hitters to end game.

Among top rated players still on board for #Brewers: prep SS Kahlil Watson, prep OF Will Taylor, Boston College CF Sal Frelick, Texas RHP Ty Madden, UCLA SS Matt McLain and Kansas State LHP Jordan Wicks.
Giants pick RHP Will Bednar at No. 14 out of Mississippi State. #Brewers are on the clock.
Andrew Painter becomes second prep pitcher drafted at No. 13 by Philadelphia.

One against the #Brewers.
Yes, the umpiring has been bad (for both sides), but that's not why Brewers have dropped two in a row to Reds  https://t.co/zkRygPUpKM via @journalsentinel
Scary, scary story.
The commissioner's office should be fining the umpires, not the players, but of course they can't and won't because of the union thing.
Damn. Terrible year for injuries and now one of the best joins the casualty list.
More from Counsell on Libka's call: "It's an umpire getting involved when there wasn't any reason to be involved."

#Brewers manager Craig Counsell on umpire John Libka's call on Yelich on 1B line: "That's a clear case of an umpire kind of making something up or thinking he sees something that has no influence on the game, and then making a call. There's nothing there."
#Brewers manager Craig Counsell on the umpiring in this series: "I feel like it's been a rough series for the umpires. There's a lot of guys upset on both teams."

#Brewers catcher Omar Narvaez on the ball-strikes call by Doug Eddings crew in series: "It's been really unbelievable, what we've been seeing these last 3 days. It's out of our control. We've got to keep pushing and playing hard and try to adjust to what baseball is giving us."
#Brewers pitcher Freddy Peralta on the umpiring by Doug Eddings crew: "They are doing a really bad job. First game, second game and tonight, too. They need to be better on both sides, like I said."

#Brewers Freddy Peralta said the umps in this series "need to be be better on both sides." Said ball-strike calls have been bad in all three games and reiterated "on both sides." Said he thought the 2-2 slider to Castellanos was right on bottom of strike zone.
As we go to ninth at American Family Field, it's #Brewers 3, Reds 3 and umpires 3 (ejections).

Willy Adames is angry at umpire for not giving him time as he stepped out on a strike. And now Brach is mad the ump didn't give him strike three call on next pitch. This would be funny if it wasn't so sad. As I said, umps are THE story in series. Ain't supposed to be that way.
Yes, and he just gave the ump the stare about it. One thing you have to say about this. Umps are equal opportunity bad in this series.

Tyrone Taylor, who replaced Christian Yelich when he was ejected in the sixth, blasts a two-run homer off Brad Brach in the eighth to tie it. Brach wasn't happy with ball-strike calls on walk to Urias before the homer but what's new. That's the way this series has rolled.
Yes, the fans came to watch umps eject Craig Counsell, Christian Yelich and Joey Votto. Great promotion for the game on a national TV broadcast.

Onward with the umpire crap show in Milwaukee. Now it's the Reds who get a taste of it as third base umpire Doug Eddings ejects Joey Votto over a check-swing call. These umps have been THE story of the series, not the players. MLB should be so proud.
Amir Garrett strikes out the side in the #Brewers seventh. Reds still lead 3-1.

Vladimir Gutierrez out of game for Cincy. #Brewers won't be sorry to see him go even though he had no strikeouts in six innings. In three starts against them, he has allowed five runs in 19 innings (2.37 ERA).
Check out India's tag of Yelich. Does it look like he thinks Yelich is going to be called out? Methinks not.
#Brewers try to score Narvaez from first base on double into LF corner by Garcia but Reds make perfect relay 7-6-2 to get him at the plate and Cincy keeps 3-1 lead after six.
This umpiring crew has distinguished itself in all of the wrong ways. They have become THE story of the series. They are not supposed to be THE story.

The umpire crap show continues at American Family Field. Christian Yelich safe at first on wild throw on bunt attempt. Makes a slight move but no real attempt to go to second. India tags him and umpire John Libka calls him out. An irate Yelich gets tossed and crowd is going nuts.
Brent Suter comes in and mows down next three hitters but Reds have 3-1 lead boing to bottom of sixth.

What Peralta needed was the "everything is a strike" zone by O'Nora and Eddings in first two games of series. Then, Counsell figured Peralta got squeezed, and that's enough. Morales paying for the sins of his fellow umps in previous two games, and there were many.

Freddy Peralta hangs a 3-2 slider to Castellanos and he knocks it out for a three-run homer to give Reds a 3-1 lead. He is out of the game and now Counsell has been ejected by home plate umpire Gabe Morales.

Freddy Peralta nicks India with a pitch (he didn't try to avoid it) and then Jesse Winker beats the shift by bouncing a grounder through the left side for the Reds' first hit of the game. Two on, no outs, for the heart of Cincy lineup, beginning with Castellanos.
Freddy Peralta has allowed no hits through five innings but also has thrown 82 pitches, which is a lot. #Brewers lead 1-0.

Cherington on coming to the No. 1 conclusion: "It was close. Henry was on top, but it was close. They all have different strengths. ‚Ä¶ At the end of the day, you want to feel good about the person you're betting on. ‚Ä¶ We feel really good about the person we're betting on here."

Cherington saw Davis at the Draft Combine: "I think it says something about him ... that he committed to going to the combine. Obviously, he was a kid who knew he was going pretty high in the Draft [but he went] down there and continued to challenge himself to get better."
Cherington on what stands out about Davis' makeup: "Just that he's dying to get better all the time." Said he's willing to be challenged and get outside his comfort zone.

On the 10-game penalty:  ‚ÄúWe have to play a man down, so that pretty much affects the entire team. I‚Äôm not going to be that selfish to go out there and risk that for my team, so we‚Äôre gonna follow the rules and whatever happens happens...

On his career:  "I‚Äôm just grateful that I got this far into my career before we got to this point... I‚Äôm going to figure it out. I made it through 4IP with pretty much all fastballs tonight, so IDK. Maybe I‚Äôll have to develop another pitch, maybe I‚Äôll start learning a changeup."

On divide between hitters and pitchers:  ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt we want both sides competing? If one side has to concede and the other side gets all the advantage, then what are we doing here? We‚Äôre just watering down the purity of competing in the game.‚Äù

...Rosin by itself doesn‚Äôt do anything for anybody. I don‚Äôt know anybody that just uses rosin. If we can somehow get a rosin bag that actually worked, I think that‚Äôs something that should definitely be looked into.‚Äù

...It literally, it barely even dries up sweat. It might as well not even be there. I can‚Äôt even think how many times over the course of my career that I‚Äôve gone to the back of the rosin bag. Sometimes I‚Äôve been on mounds that didn‚Äôt even have rosin bags on the back of the mound.

On previous routine:  ‚ÄúAs soon as I get to the field every day, I put sunscreen on. Now I can‚Äôt do that. And on top of that, the only thing that‚Äôs provided is the rosin bag on the back of the mound, which to be honest with you, is completely useless. It does nothing...

On getting hurt:  ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt remember a game where I‚Äôve gripped a baseball that hard. I def. use a loose grip.  I even hit two guys and I don‚Äôt hit people. I don‚Äôt hit people. With two strikes, too. Trying to go fastballs in and just missing up and in, but not really knowing why."

A smattering:   ‚ÄúI think tonight spoke for itself. I‚Äôm not going to get caught up in (the new rules). But I‚Äôll definitely say it‚Äôs starting to affect people, people in their careers. So, we‚Äôre going to follow the rules, but this is the game you‚Äôre going to get.‚Äù

Cherington, on what separated Davis: "There were a number of players we liked. It was close. I do believe with every pick but certainly particular at 1:1, you want to feel good about the person you're betting on. We feel really good about the person we're betting on in Henry."

Cherington, on whether Henry Davis will sign for under slot at No. 1: "Ultimately, we want to sign the players we take. We wanted to do right by the process first, which is really debate that top group. ... We haven't signed him. But we take him with some confidence that we can."

Cherington, on drafting greatest organizational need: "We did not take him because he's a catcher but I know one of the things he feels strongly about is helping the guys around him, especially the pitchers. ... We took him because he was the top player on our board."

Cherington: We did have a lot of debate. There's good player at top of this draft. Ultimately, as we got done with our meetings, we had Henry at the top of our board.  You're obviously betting on talent at top of draft. You're also betting on the person. We believe in the person.

Pirates GM Ben Cherington on No. 1 pick: * Calls Henry Davis a really good offensive performer who controlled strike zone.  * Says Davis has a good rep for handling pitching staff, improved blocking and receiving since HS * Mentions his "desire to get better"
Cherington said he spent a lot of time with Henry Davis at MLB combine but also time before and after.

What stood out about Davis' personality? Cherington: Just his desire to get better all the time, willingness to be challenged, get outside his comfort zone. Wants to impact the clubhouse he's in in a positive way. Checks a lot of boxes. Thrilled to add him to our organization.
Pirates GM Ben Cherington says that, as of last night, Henry Davis was at the top of their board.  Then starts breaking up on the video call.

Sorry, I misunderstood this. House said he went to Nats Park when he was 12, not in '12. (Still, that's only a difference of 3 years, which will make you feel really old regardless.)
Also, Brady House said he went to a game at Nationals Park in 2012 and he's been watching Trea Turner since he debuted in 2015. (House would've been 9 in 2012 and 12 in 2015.)
House also reiterated his determination to keep playing shortstop. He's already 6-4, 210 pounds, but he compares himself to Trevor Story and believes he can handle the shortstop position long-term.

Brady House is committed to play at the Univ. of Tennessee. Just told us on Zoom he intends to sign with the Nationals, provided the negotiations work out. As the No. 11 pick, his designated slot bonus amount is a bit more than $4.5 million.
Brady House is only the 2nd position player the Nationals have used with their first pick in their last 8 drafts. The other was Carter Kieboom, another high school shortstop from Georgia.
With the No. 11 pick (their highest since Anthony Rendon in 2011), the Nationals have drafted Georgia high school shortstop Brady House.
The Nationals are now on the clock, and Kumar Rocker is no longer on the board. Several other high-profile college pitchers, however, are still available.
The Mets are on the clock, the Nationals are right behind them, and Kumar Rocker is still on the board ...

Brault update
Will Craig is exploring opportunities with teams in Asia, which is why he was a late scratch from last night's Class AAA Indianapolis game last night, Cherington says.

Ben Cherington says No. 10 prospect Carmen Mlodzinski "felt a little stiffness." Don't think it's too serious, but pulling him from the game last night was precautionary.  "We're trying to be cautious with guys and catch things early when we can."

Ben Cherington says Ke'Bryan Hayes and Jacob Stallings are just scheduled off days.  Says that Polanco, Tom, Moran, Evans are progressing well.  Evans and Tom have both "initiated baseball activity" in Pittsburgh.

Ben Cherington asked if the potential of robo umps in the future changes how they approach talent acquisition or analysis. He says they need to be "prepared" for the possibility but not "planning" for it.
Ben Cherington says the Pirates have communicated with all the representatives of the players in the mix for 1:1, and that those conversations will continue today.
Ben Cherington says it's "way more likely than not" that the Pirates take right up until 7:00 tonight to decide on the first pick.

Ben Cherington says the Pirates "are not aware" of who they're going to pick. Adds that it's "going to come out of a certain group that we've identified."   Pirates are now talking to those players and they're taking right up to draft time to make the final decision.

Ben Cherington making it sound on his radio show like the Pirates' draft preparation consisted of locking all the amateur scouts in a room and challenging (yelling at) each other.   Cherington says he was encouraged that things got loud at times and feels they are well prepared.

The Giants won, 3-1, to finish off a three-game sweep of the Nationals.   At 57-32, they'll head into the All-Star break with the best record in baseball for the seventh time in franchise history and the first time since 2016.

Kevin Gausman will depart with the bases loaded and no outs in the seventh inning. He's walking off to a nice ovation from the crowd here at Oracle Park.   Dominic Leone is coming in to try to protect the Giants' 3-0 lead.
Curt Casali hammered a three-run shot to give the Giants a 3-0 lead in the second inning.
The Giants recalled Caleb Baragar and optioned Tyler Beede.

Mike Elias on the remainder of the draft: "We feel very well equipped here to make some aggressive moves."
Mike Elias on whether this was an "underslot" pick: "You take the guy you want to take, and that's what we did here."
Mike Elias said Colton Cowser projects to stay in center field.   "Can't have too many center fielders."
Mike Elias: "We got our guy."
Mike Elias called Colton Cowser "an elite contact hitter," praising his ability to hit for power without striking out.
Mike Elias: "Colton [Cowser] has been and is one of the best pure hitters in the country since setting foot on campus at Sam Houston State."

If the team isn't 100% sure a pick will sign & they value someone else about the same, it might not be worth the hassle to take their primary target. Going with #2 would give them a bigger budget for later rounds to try to convince HS players to sign, rather than hit college (3/

It's not *likely* that the guy goes back to school, but it's also not unprecedented (see: Brady Aiken in 2014).   In this situation, it's important to note: Leiter comes from a pretty wealthy family. Delaying the $ for a year is less a risk for them than a kid who doesn't. (2/ )

Here's the nuance (I'm making up these numbers, btw, I don't have figures)‚Ä¶  If you tell all the other teams: "I won't sign for less than $10m" but tell Boston "I'll sign for slot" then teams have to decide if you're bluffing. No team wants to waste a top-3 pick. (1/ )

I'll answer in hypotheticals:   If a team's top target is demanding x amount over slot, the question becomes "how much better than the next guy do we think he is?" If it's only a little, it probably makes sense to take the next guy and have more flexibility later.

@xwOBAc0n The short version: if you get a player who isn‚Äôt significantly worse, but you save a few million that you can use in later rounds to overpay and convince HS players who were planning to go to college to instead sign, it can make for a better overall draft class

If you‚Äôre advising a pitcher, with a pitcher‚Äôs arm and all the inherent risks that implies, do you let them pass up #2 pick money to go back and pitch in college?  Again, not impossible, but that would certainly be a decision.

If it‚Äôs not Leiter, I get the strong sense that it will be because he effectively convinced teams that his signing bonus price is higher for non-Boston teams.  But would he really go back to school if picked 2nd? I suppose it‚Äôs possible, but I would genuinely be surprised.

Ballgame.  The Cardinals hit three home runs for the first time in almost exactly a month. All came in one inning. They were more than enough help for Kwang Hyun Kim, who owns two straight scoreless starts, and was amped.  The #STLCards win, 6-0. They are 44-46.

That base hit was the 2,064th of Yadier Molina's career, moving him into a tie for fifth all-time in Cardinals history, with Hall of Famer Enos Slaughter.  He'll almost certainly move into fourth this year, now just nine base knocks behind close pal Albert Pujols' 2,073 mark.
Paul DeJong's mama was in attendance for his homer tonight, his second in as any days, which is very, very sweet

Tommy Edman this season, left-handed: 304 plate appearances, .244/.283/.324, 2 HR, 67 OPS+  Tommy Edman this season, right-handed (entering today): 78 plate appearances, .310/.364/.521, 2 HR, 133 OPS+  Now you add that two-run homer, and every single one of those numbers rise
Paul Goldschmidt just left Wrigley Field at 112.2 mph. A gaudy 441 feet.  He's been on base three times already in five innings. Only this time, he didn't stay on any of those bases.
Kwang Hyun Kim status: Amped  https://t.co/Q2tdzhWRsc

Cardinals scouting director Randy Flores pulling out all the verbiage on first-round pick Michael McGreevy:  "He reeks of athleticism."  "He almost has a phobia of walking batters."
